FacilityName: Preferred Freezer Services of South Florida, LLC

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Compressors, Vessels, Condensers, Evaporators, AutoPurger, Gas Detectors, and Piping
_prev_prog_3.Description: A management system is in place at the Facility to oversee implementation of the Facility's PSM and RMP Program. This management system is based on the 14 elements of OSHA's Process Safety Management Program, establishes procedures and tools to implement the program, and ensures that lines of authority and responsibility are clearly defined to ensure that all elements of PSM and RMP are implemented. The person who has the overall responsibility for RMP and PSM program implementation at the Facility is the General Manager.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Preferred Freezer Services of South Florida, LLC has implemented an Accidental Release Prevention Program (PSM/RMP Program) for the Facility located at 12855 NW 113th Court, Miami, Florida 33178. The Facility is located in an urban setting with a mixture of light commercial and industrial uses in the immediate area. The PSM/RMP Program was developed in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and EPA's Accidental Release Prevention, Risk Management Plan (RMP) Rule (40 CFR 68), authorized under Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act (CAA). The Facility uses anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance listed in Appendix A of 29 CFR 1910.119 and in 40 CFR 68.130.



The primary business of the Preferred Freezer Services facility is to provide refrigerated warehousing and storage for various food products. Anhydrous ammonia is contained within a closed-loop refrigeration system consisting of vessels, compressors, evaporative condensers, evaporators and associated piping and valves. The refrigeration system cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order provide refrigeration for dock operations and cooler/freezer storage. Typical operating conditions range from 3.6 psig on the low pressure side of the system to 180 psig on the high side of the system. The maximum intended refrigerant charge within the closed-loop system is approximately 13,367 pounds. The Facility does not use any other chemicals or flammable materials in excess of threshold quantities covered by RMP requirements. 



EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule requires that facilities that have covered processes establish RMPs to reduce the risks of accidental release of toxic or flammable materials, and establish emergency response procedures in the event of an accident. This Executive Summary summarizes the efforts that Preferred Freezer S

ervices has undertaken to establish a RMP in conjunction with their PSM Program. 



A management system has been implemented at the Facility to oversee implementation of the Facility's PSM/RMP Program. This management system is based on the 14 elements of OSHA's Process Safety Management standard, establishes procedures and tools to implement the program, and ensures that lines of authority and responsibility are clearly defined to ensure that all elements of PSM and RMP are implemented. The person who has the overall responsibility for RMP and PSM program implementation at the Facility is the General Manager. 



The Facility has adopted consensus guidelines published by the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating, and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE) and the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) as recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices. 



Ammonia safety considerations have been incorporated into the installation and operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. Compressors are provided with micro-controllers, and a refrigeration control system monitors system operation. Pressure vessels are appropriately rated for pressure and temperature, and are provided with dual pressure relief valves that discharge into an engineered relief vent discharge header. Piping systems and vessels are appropriately insulated to prevent corrosion, and inspections are conducted on refrigeration system components under the Facility's Mechanical Integrity program. The Facility utilizes ammonia sensors within the Compressor Room and throughout the cold storage areas (freezers and dock); gas detection alarms are programmed to shut down affected subsystems of the refrigeration system. The Compressor Room is provided with fire sprinkler protection, and continuous mechanical exhaust to provide ventilation pursuant to recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.



Preferred Freezer Services has performed a Process Hazard Anal

ysis (PHA) on the refrigeration system design to evaluate potential hazards and the consequences of deviation from design intent. The PHA study was performed according to guidelines for hazard evaluation procedures established by the American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE), Center for Chemical Process Safety (CCPS). The PHA was performed by a team of subject matter experts in refrigeration system engineering, operations and maintenance, and environmental, health, and safety. For deviations resulting in a safety or environmental consequences, the PHA team determined the relative risk of the deviation based on the Likelihood and Severity of the occurrence using a risk ranking methodology. When the protective devices (hardware, software, procedures, etc.) did not, by the consensus of the PHA team, adequately mitigate potential adverse consequences, the team assigned recommended action items (recommendations) intended to improve the controls and safeguards to further mitigate risk. These corrective actions were recorded and tracked to resolution. 



Refrigeration equipment is maintained in accordance with original equipment manufacturer (OEM) specifications, applicable codes, and industry standards. Preferred Freezer Services has implemented a Mechanical Integrity Program for the ammonia refrigeration system in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119(j) and 40 CFR 68.73. The purpose is to verify that critical process equipment is designed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of release of anhydrous ammonia. Facility personnel perform daily, weekly, monthly, quarterly, semi-annual, and annual inspections of ammonia refrigeration equipment, and a system integrity check is conducted every 5 years by a qualified third-party. The Facility has adopted guidance from IIAR Bulletin 110 for conducting these inspections.



All new employees, regardless of position, are provided with ammonia awareness training. Special emphasis is placed on the hazards of anhydrous am

monia and actions of all personnel in case of an ammonia release. Only qualified persons are hired for operations and maintenance of the refrigeration system, and these employees are provided on-the-job training before they are permitted to work on, operate, or otherwise manipulate or affect the ammonia refrigeration system. The demonstration and on-the-job training that they receive cover the physical properties of ammonia and detailed instruction on operating the ammonia refrigeration system, including understanding responding to upset conditions on the ammonia refrigeration system. The Facility has also implemented a formal Contractor Safety Program to address work on or around the refrigeration system by contractor personnel.



Monthly PSM/RMP topics are provided by Preferred Freezer Services' corporate office for review by the General Manager with personnel under the Facility's Employee Participation Program. These monthly topics are intended to improve safety and performance through refreshing knowledge on specific PSM/RMP program elements, through sharing published information from recent industry-related Chemical Safety Board investigations, or sharing published information about recent OSHA/EPA enforcement activities related to PSM/RMP compliance.



The Facility has established a Refrigeration Emergency Response Plan (RERP). Refrigeration operators are trained in the RERP and it is reviewed annually to verify that it is current with Facility operating practice. The plan contains protocols and emergency response procedures to initiate an emergency shutdown of the refrigeration system, and for emergency notifications.  A list of the agencies that must be notified upon a reportable quantity release are included in the RERP to assure the facility meets its reporting obligations and that the public is properly notified in the event of an emergency. Further, the RERP contains a list for internal notifications, and contact information for the refrigeration contr

actor and emergency response clean-up contractor. All facility personnel receive annual training in emergency sheltering and evacuation procedures under the Facility's Emergency Action Plan. 



To date, the Facility's Five Year History does not include any accidental releases from the ammonia system that resulted in any of the following (onsite or offsite): deaths, injuries, significant property damage, evacuations, sheltering in place, environmental damage, or a reportable quantity of ammonia released to the atmosphere.



In 2014, the Facility conducted a triennial PSM/RMP compliance audit to review implementation of the PSM/RMP program, verify that procedures and practices are adequate and are being followed, and to identify opportunities to improve safety. In 2015, the facility improved the pressure relief vent header and installed a transfer vessel to improve safety and system operation. The next revalidation of the PHA is scheduled for 2016.
